//Description Learn all kinds of information about alcohol and how to drink it safely Learn about the various consequences of drinking alcohol as a way to motivate yourself to control your drinking Use the standard drink calculator to calculate the amount of alcohol to be consumed and get advice to avoid drinking too much With a fun meme, a daily reminder to keep your drinking in check Five Six Seven
Alcohol Information Drinking Alarm Drinking Calculator Drinking Recognition Drinking Quiz Drink Consequence Sobriety Reminder Achievement
Standard Drink What is Standard Drink? What is a Standard Drink?
Australia's national alcohol guidelines use the 'standard drink' as a measure of alcohol consumed. One standard drink is defined as containing 10 grams of alcohol. (12.5ml approx. of pure alcohol) What is the Limit?
Assuie health experts recommend no more than 4 standard drinks a day and no more than 10 standard drinks in any given week. Our Handy Guilde can help you Standard Drink
=

·Wine 13% alcohol, 100ml average serving

·Sparkling wine 13% alcohol, 100ml

·Full Strength Beer 4.9% alcohol, 285ml glass

·Light Beer 2.7% alcohol, 425ml glass

·Cider 4.9% alcohol, 285ml glass
Alcohol Type Common Alcohol Types Beer Beer is a strong alcoholic beverage prepared from malt that has been fermented with yeast and hops. Lager, Ale, Craft Beer, and other varieties of beer exist. The Latin word "bibere," which means to drink, is where the term "beer" originates. Wine Wine is typically a fermented grape-based alcoholic beverage. The sugar in the grapes is consumed by yeast, who then transforms it into ethanol and carbon dioxide. Red wine and white wine are the two categories into which most wines fall. Whiskey / Bourbon A type of American whisky made from rye and maize is called bourbon. A spirit called whisky is created by distilling malted grains, particularly barley or rye. Whiskey is not always whisky, while vice versa is true of bourbon. In order to distinguish itself from whisky, bourbon must be produced in the United States using at least 51% maize. Vodka An alcoholic beverage with Russian roots, vodka is produced by distilling rye, wheat, or potatoes. It is distilled liquor with an alcohol concentration of between 40 and 55 percent. It is clear and colourless and has any discernible scent or flavour. Rum Rum is an alcoholic beverage created by fermenting and distilling sugarcane juice or molasses. In most cases, oak barrels are used to mature the distillate, a transparent liquid. Nearly all of the world's sugar-producing regions also produce rum. Gin A fermentable grain, starch, or fruit, juniper berries, and additional botanicals are used to make gin. The spirit must include juniper and have a volume alcohol content of at least 40% in order to be categorised as gin. Gin differs from other alcoholic beverages because botanicals are used in the distilling process. Tequila Tequila is a Mexican alcoholic beverage that is primarily created from the fermented sap of blue agave plants that have undergone two successive distillations. Tequila has fewer calories, no sugar, and no carbohydrates, making it a potentially healthier alternative to some other types of alcohol. Brandy Brandy is an alcoholic beverage made by distilling wine or a fruit mash with yeast. Brandies manufactured from wines or fermented mashes of other fruits are frequently referred to by the name of the specific fruit; the term used alone normally refers to the grape product.
Hangover Remedy Drink Guideline Hangover Remedies Drink Guideline Before Drink Guideline After Drink Guideline
Eat before Drink When you start drinking, the alcohol will reach your bloodstream more quickly if your stomach is empty. However, food will slow the flow, which allows more time for alcohol to break down. Thus, eating before your drink is essential. Stay Hydrated Alcohol will dehydrate your body. Hydration is vital even if you are not thirsty. Keep in mind that drinking water in between every few drinks can help you stay hydrated. Don’t Drink too Fast Your body can only process one standard drink per hour. So keep in mind that don’t drink too fast. Take your time to handle one standard drink before drinking the next one. You can always dilute the alcohol with water or juice. Know Your Limit Australian Guidelines suggest adults should intake no more than 4 standard drinks per day or 10 standard drinks during one week. Thus, you should know your limit before drinking and drink no more than the recommended amount of alcohol. Count Your Drink Set yourself a drinking limit before the first drink and stick to it. People often drink more than they realise. Rather than topping up your glass, you should finish your drink before starting a new one. Therefore, you know how many drinks you have taken. Avoid drinking in rounds as well. Learn to Say No Sometimes it is hard to say “NO thanks” to others, especially when peer pressure is hard to resist. However, regardless of what others are saying or doing, it is unnecessary to follow them. Saying NO won’t hurt anyone, but can protect yourself. Don’t Drink and Drive It is against Law to drive with a BAC above 0.05 for full-license drivers and a BAC of 0.00 for Learner and Probationary drivers in Australia. The more drinks you have, the higher chance for you to have car accidents. It will hurt you and others on the road. Please don’t drink and drive. Plan how to get home early (Uber, Public Transport, Friend who doesn’t drink, etc.)
Get some Sleep Lie in bed and sleep! Sleep is always the cure. Even sleeping for two hours is going to help you recover from the hangover! Drink some Water or Juice Alcohol will dehydrate your body, your body needs hydration! So the first thing you wake up in the morning should be drinking some water or juice! Get some Vitamins Your body needs Vitamin supplement after consuming alcohol. The most convenient way is to drink orange juice to gain Vitamin C. Zinc and Vitamin B are helpful to hangover relief. Eat some Food Maybe right now you don’t want to eat yet, but eating is good to recover from a hangover. Don’t eat too much food or unhealthy food. You should intake food with high protein. Exercise Appropriate amount of exercise is going to wake up your body, enhance metabolism. Taking some fresh air while walking can be helpful. Take a Shower Take a shower after a hangover. A shower can not only clean up your body, but also wake your body up. Cold or hot water is either fine for you. Use Hair of Dog The hair of a dog is not the hair of a dog. It is an alcoholic drink that can help you recover from a hangover. Though the hair of a dog can be helpful, it can only relieve it for a short amount of time. Please use it with caution.
Quit Drinking Timeline Quit Drinking Timeline 12 hours Withdrawal symptoms appear, possible shaking, vomiting, sweating, mania, and anxiety.
1 day Withdrawal symptoms persist. Craving for alcohol, fatigue, low mood, sleep disturbance.
2 days A dangerous period. More serious withdrawal symptoms occur, such as rapid heartbeat, increased blood pressure, and convulsions.
3 days For most people, this is when withdrawal symptoms begin to subside or become more manageable.
5 days For most people, withdrawal symptoms will end at this point. For a small number of people, withdrawal symptoms may worsen and develop into more severe symptoms.
1 week Sleep quality may begin to improve, and it may take a month or more for some people to get better sleep.
2 weeks You may start to lose weight due to reduced alcohol calorie intake. Fatty livers not severely damaged by alcohol consumption begin to show signs of recovery.
1 month Those with high blood pressure due to alcohol consumption may have their blood pressure lowered to a healthier level. Your skin may look healthier.
1 year Among some people, hangover symptoms such as fatigue, sleep disturbance may persist for a long time, but after 12 months of abstinence, symptoms disappear in almost all people. The health benefits of quitting drinking begin to show up.

Tips
Healthy man and woman should drink no more than 10 Standard Drink per week, and no more than 4 Standard Drink on any one day. Recommendation Still under a safe condition, you can continue drinking. No more than 2 standard drinks within 1 hour, consider taking a break. You are reaching the daily limit, please consider stopping drinking. You have exceeded the daily drinking limit, please stop drinking. You have exceeded your weekly limit of alcohol consumption! Please stop this drinking spree now!
What is this? This Sobriety Reminder aims to provide you with occasional Meme tips in a period of time you specify on how to control your drinking to help you strengthen your resolve and will to control your drinking, with the added benefit of helping you collect funny Meme about alcohol How it works? 1. Click Start and End button to select your favorite reminding time range.

2. Turn on the switch.

3. Done! We will push you the notification at your selected time range. You have been drinking for Recommendation Meme description Once you click on the notification card, your selected favourite sentence will be displayed here Today's Meme
Law Consequence Moral Consequence Health Consequence Health Consequence
Drunk in a public place There are three offences under the Act that can result in an arrest and charges if you are drunk in a public place.

Offence 1: Drunk in a public place
If your speech, coordination, balance, or behaviour is noticeably altered and the police feel it is because you have been drinking alcohol, they may think you are drunk.

Offence 2:Drunk and disorderly in a public place
Being drunk and acting in a way that disrupts the peace, interferes with others, or is perceived to be doing so.

Offence 3:Drunk and behaving in a riotous or disorderly manner
Getting drunk and behaving in a way that makes a member of the public worry about a possible violation of the peace. Additionally, if the authorities believe your behaviour is extreme, they may charge you with this more serious version of the disorderly offence.

If you’re convicted of one of these offences, you’ll incur a penalty:

Drunk in a public place
A maximum of 8 penalty units. (8 penalty units = $1321.76)

Drunk and disorderlyfirst offence (a maximum of 20 penalty units or 3 days in prison). Second or subsequent offence (20 penalty units or 1 month in prison). (20 penalty units = $33043.40)

Drunk and behaving in a riotous or disorderly mannermaximum of 10 penalty units or prison for 2 months. (10 penalty units = $1652.20)

A penalty unit is how a fine is calculated. The amount of one penalty unit is indexed and increases each year on 1 July. Currently, one penalty unit is $165.22. Buying Alcohol or going to other licensed premises If you’re under 18, you’re Not allowed to buy alcohol, even if you’re buying it for an adult (someone over the age of 18).

If you ask your friends (over 18) to buy alcohol for you, and they give you the alcohol, they can get fined.

If you are under 18, you are Not allowed to be in a licensed place (such as a bar or pub) where alcohol is served unless one or more of the following applies:

·you are with a responsible adult

·you are having a meal

·you are a resident of the licensed place

·you are employed by the licensed venue but not involved in the supply of alcohol

·you are completing an approved training program in hospitality.

You, the person who is serving you, and the owner of the licensed place, can be fined if you’re caught and do not satisfy one or more of the above categories.

A liquor licensee can be fined up to $19,343 for selling alcohol to a minor. Underage Drinking in Private Homes ·In their own homes, parents or guardians are permitted to provide alcohol to their own children under the age of 18.

·It is against the law to serve alcohol to a minor in another person's house without their parent or legal guardian's consent. The maximum fine for adults is $19,343.

·Anyone planning a party for youngsters under the age of 18 is advised to obtain their parents' or guardians' written consent. This also holds true for social visits.

·According to the Liquor Control Reform Act, adults must show that they are responsibly supervising the supply of alcohol to anyone under the age of 18 in their residence. Drink and Drive in Victoria ·In Victoria and all other states and territories, the legal blood alcohol concentration (BAC) limit for drivers with a full licence is 0.05.

A BAC of zero is mandatory for drivers with a probationary licence (P plates) or learner's permit (L plates), bus and taxi drivers, and drivers of trucks exceeding 15 tonnes.

·If you are convicted of drunk driving, you could be subject to harsh punishments:

		-Loss of licence

		-Fines

		-Imprisonment

·Any vehicle you drive must have an alcohol interlock that has been authorised by VicRoads installed if you lose your licence or learner permit as a result of drunk driving. You must do this in order to get your licence or permission reissued.

·Even if there is no alcohol detected in the driver's blood or breath, drinking alcohol while operating a vehicle or while seated next to a learner driver is illegal.

·Drivers who are caught operating a vehicle in Victoria with having illegal drugs in their system and a blood or BAC reading above the legal limit face significant penalties.
Moral Definition Moral standardsare those that are concerned with or relate to how people behave, particularly how to distinguish between right and wrong behaviour. Moral standards are the guidelinesthat people have for the kinds of behaviours they consider to be ethically acceptable and unacceptable. Alcohol Affects Moral You may experience relaxation, reduced anxiety, and more confidence after consuming alcohol because it has an impact on the area of your brain that regulates inhibition. However, these results disappear shortly. Regardless of how you are feeling, the chemical changes in your brain can quickly cause more unpleasant emotions, including anger, melancholy, or anxiety.

According to a recent study, excessive alcohol use may affect men's capacity for empathy and ironic perception. According to the study, long-term heavy drinking may harm brain regions responsible for perceiving humour and emotion.
Moral Definition Alcohol-related causes account for about 2.5 million deaths globally each year. Alcohol abuse is a contributing factor in more than 200 illnesses that cause injury and harm. Alcohol is one of the top killers in the world. Short Term Effect After drinking alcohol, the following day, you might experience a hangover, which may include the following:

·Headache

·Diarrhoea, nausea and vomiting

·Tiredness and trembling

·Increased heart rate and blood pressure

·Trouble concentrating / Walking / Breathing / Controlling

·Anxiety

·Poor or decreased sleep

·Coma

·Death Long Term Effect ·Mental health issue, higher chance of suicide

·Depression, anxiety, alcoholism, dependence on alcohol.

·Weight gain

·Diabetes

·Erectile dysfunction

·Cancer

·Difficulties with male infertility including low sperm counts and low testosterone levels

·Brain damage, dementia and stroke

·High blood pressure, heart damage, and heart attacks

·Liver failure Alcohol Poisoning When drinking a lot of alcohol, the central nervous system is impacted, which slows heart and breathing rate. Additionally, it disrupts the gag reflex. If the drinker drops out from too much drinking, this raises the possibility of choking on vomit.

Alcohol poisoning may be present in someone if they become disoriented, vomit, have a seizure, have pale complexion, or pass out. The followings are the potential symptoms:

·Seizure

·Vomiting

·Confusion

·Unconsciousness

·Very slow breathing rate

·Unresponsiveness Alcoholism The word "alcoholism" is frequently applied to more serious alcohol use disorders. Some common symptoms of this disease are:

Craving: The person has an extreme hunger for drinking.

Loss of control: Once the person starts drinking, stopping becomes difficult. They might be unable to refrain from drinking or limit their consumption.

Tolerance: To feel the effects of alcohol, the person needs to consume more of it.

Less consciousness: The effects of their prolonged drinking are hidden from them.

Many sufferers of severe AUD are unable to quit drinking on their own. With their condition, they require outside assistance.

Our application seeks to help older teenagers to consume alcohol responsibly.
Am I Drinking Too Much? It's just a social event, I'm just celebrating this week; I'm sorry I'm too stressed, so I'd like to have a few drinks; you can always find a good excuse to drink.

Don't make alcohol consumption a habit, find out how it impacts your life.

With this short quiz, you will find out if your drinking habit has negatively impacted your life, and wha you can do to make a change. Select "Yes" if this statement applies to you Take the quiz Take Quiz Again YES NO
Quiz 1
Quiz 2
Quiz 3
Quiz 4
Quiz 5
Quiz 6
Quiz 7
Quiz 8
Quiz 9
Quiz 10
Quiz 11
Quiz 12
Quiz 13
In more than one case, I've consumed more alcohol or drank for a longer time than I intended.
Once I start drinking, I can't limit how much I drink.
It has been difficult for me to cut down or stop drinking more than once.
I drink a lot and am hung over most of the time.
There were times, it was impossible to think of anything else I just needed a drink.
As a result of my drinking and hangovers, I have been unable to attend home, school, work or my family.
Despite the fact that it was causing problems with my relationships, I continued to drink.
Drinking has forced me to give up activities/hobbies that matter to me and my wellbeing.
In the past, I have done things that increased my chances of getting hurt when I was drinking, such as driving and swimming after drinking.
The drinking has caused depression and anxiety symptoms in me, but I continue to do it anyway.
Over the course of a few drinks, I've blacked out or forgotten what happened.
My tolerance to alcohol has increased over time as I have drank more.
After not drinking for a period of time, I've experienced withdrawal symptoms, including sleep problems, agitation, anxiety, depression, restlessness, nausea.The symptoms have been avoided by drinking.
Your Result: You do not demonstrate any of the symptoms associated with problematic drinking according to a clinical definition. In any case, you should feel free to skip drinking alcohol if you feel that it is negatively affecting your wellbeing or life in anyway. You may have a mild drinking problem, or "Grey Area Drinking." We recommend starting a personalized program to either reduce or eliminate your drinking. You may have a moderarte drinking problem. We recommend you try to stop drinking excessive alcohol and seek help from medical experts when possible. It is likely that you suffer from an Alcohol Use Disorder. For more information on treatment for Alcohol Use Disorder, please contact a licensed mental health professional.
